SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering the questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; other may prove impossible for you to answer. So don't worry about leaving blank spaces; other questions may provide the chance to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1911 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer List: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark [here] and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

[ ] All questionnaires
[ ] Pioneer health conditions
[ ] Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
[ ] Pioneer housing
[ ] Pioneer education and churchwork
[ ] Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Division,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A WORD OF EXPLANATION TO THE PERSON

SUBMITTING THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Be sure to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1922, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadians Eat? is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Canadian Questionnaire No. 2 is still being circulated. If you are willing to answer this, and are willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

1. Your full name: Mrs. Ernest C. Fletcher

2. Your address: Kincaid, Sask.

3. Date: Oct 7th, 1952

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Worcester, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer and Dairyman

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): September 17th, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: England

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question. If you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens", etc.) 16

9. What were your reasons for coming West? My father wished to get more land for his growing family. Of 10 -

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) My father's brother was one of the Methodist Colonists who settled in the Pheasant Hills Colony. He preached there. Thomas Loveridge through him we came out to our land. There we located first on his homestead. Later took up other land.

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: MRS. ERNEST C. FLETCHER.
2. Your address: KINCAID, SASK.
3. Date: OCT 7 & 1952.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   WORCESTER, ENGLAND.
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   FARMER, DAIRY MAN.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   SEPTEMBER 17th, 1905.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   ENGLAND,
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you know it rather not or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.)
   I was in my teens.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   MY FATHER WISHED TO GET MORE LAND FOR HIS GROWING FAMILY OF 10 -
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    MY FATHER'S BROTHER WAS ONE OF THE METHODIST COLONISTS WHO SETTLED IN THE PHEASANT HILLS COLONY. HE PREACHED THERE. THOMAS LOVERIDGE THROUGH HIM WE CAME OUT TO TAKE UP LAND THERE. WE LOCATED FIRST ON HIS HOMESTEAD. LATER TOOK UP OTHERS LAND.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

MERE ENCOURAGING.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

FAMILY.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

SHIP. RAIL TO GREENFELL. THEN WAGONS TO PHEASANT HILLS.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

NOTHING ADVENTUROUS. BUT EXCITING TO A LARGE DEGREE.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

AT GREENFELL.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

PHEASANT HILLS, SASK.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

WINNIPEG. AFTER MARRIAGE, HAZENMORE, NOVY, KINCAID.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

NO HOUSEWORK. CLERKING.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were encouraging.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? Family.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Ship, rail to Grenfell, then wagons to Pheasant Hills.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.) Nothing adventurous. But exciting to a 16 year old.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? At Grenfell.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Pheasant Hills, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Winnipeg, after marriage Hazenmore, T. Novy, Kincaid.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Housework, clerking.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? If so, who?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? New Year's by what means of travel?

YES. SERVICES IN HOMES V SQUAD HOUSES.

NOT GREAT DISTANCES. BUT WE VISITED MY FATHER'S HOME OFTEN WITH OXEN.

SOMETIMES WITH BUGGIES OR DEMOCRATS.

EVEN RECOLLECT GOING TO CHURCH AT PHEASANT FORKS WITH OXEN.

MANY SLEIGHING PARTIES IN WINTER.

BULLING BEES, BOX SOCIALS —
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

ERNEST C. FLETCHER
NIVILLE SASK.
JUNE 26, 1913.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

No - unless it was one brother.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell me when they came and where they settled.

ALL THE FAMILY CAME OUT IN 1905
BUT ONE BROTHER WHO CAME LATER.
THEY SETTLED IN THE PHEASANT HILLS.
MANY ARE STILL THERE ON FARMS.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your mind? What would you like to record?

MANY HAPPY SOCIAL TIMES THEN -
THOSE WERE THE DAYS WHEN OXEN WERE OUR ONLY MEANS OF TRAVEL. LATER HORSES.
NEIGHBOURHOODS AND SOCIALABILITY
PREDOMINATED -

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Many came to the southwest in the land rush of 1908-1909. My husband did, later I joined him.

35. Yes, some did return. We stayed all through the drought years or were finally rewarded.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Yes! Years on church school boards. Also on council. We are both associated with church work.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were invited to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Can't say. 1st car '1916'. 1st cricket 1914.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name; (2) date of its adoption; (3) any changes in names since then; (4) date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above.

A school was named 'Cardiff' by my husband who came from Cardiff, Wales, in 1906.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

MANY CAME TO THE SOUTHWEST IN THE LAND RUSH OF 1908-1909. MY HUSBAND DID, LATER I JOINED HIM.

YES, SOME DID RETURN. WE STAYED ALK THROUGH THE DROUGHT YEARS OR WERE FINALLY REWARDED.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

YES! YEARS ON CHURCH SCHOOL BOARDS FOR MY HUSBAND. ALSO ON COUNCIL. WE ARE BOTH ASSOCIATED WITH CHURCH WORK.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "visitors" to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, etc.)

1ST CAR 1916. 1ST CRUISE 1914.
